Have you ever built something with Lego pieces? Then you had ABS (acrylonitrile butadiene styrene) in your hands. It is the most common plastic in 3D printing and that is because of its characteristic of being a flexible thermoplastic and highly resistant to shocks. Today it is used, for example, in the bodywork of cars, gears of appliances or the housings of mobile phones. PLA is really cool

No extrusion at the start of printing. No plastic comes out at the start of printing. No plastic comes out of the nozzle. The extruder is plugged Nozzle "scratches" bed
First layer does not adhere to the base At the start of printing, the first layer does not stick to the hot bed. Hotbed and nozzle First layer speed Temperature
Little plastic coming out of the nozzle Lack of plastic to properly attach perimeters and filler Diameter of filament Multiplier
A lot of plastic comes out of the nozzle Excess plastic in top layers Multiplier parameter
Holes in upper layers Holes in the upper face of the parts Upper layers Underfill Low extrusion
Threads on outside of piece Remaining threads coming off the die and sticking to the part Retraction High temperature Heavy displacements
Excess temperature deformation Detail imperfections due to overheating Layer cooling High temperature High speed
Layer displacement Miss calibration of misaligned axes is noted Hotend Belts Electronics
Clogged Filament During printing the plastic does not advance and the filament feels bitten. Hotend Speed Temperature
Extruder jammed No plastic coming out of nozzle Incorrect temperature Defective filament Disarm hotend
Stop extruding plastic Extrusion is interrupted in the middle of printing Teflon tube damaged Bitten filament Overheated engine
Deficient filling The filling is too thin and its walls do not bind properly Filling speed Change filling rate Material flow rate
Plastic stuck to piece Plastic "clumps" form and stick to the piece Shrinkage Temperature
Holes in outer layers Holes form in the top and side layers Perimeter/fill ratio Print speed Top layers
Warping In the middle of printing, the part begins to come off the hot bed Take off first layers Airflow ABS recommendations
"Scratched" top layer The nozzle leaves marks on the surface of the piece Excess plastic Z axis
Layer offset Lateral waves throughout the piece Z axis
Lines in the piece Lines and irregular finish throughout the piece Print speed Acceleration Mechanical
Lack of filling Lack of material in thin walls Filling Perimeters
Low resolution Small details do not print or do not print correctly Incorrect nozzle Nozzle Settings Redesign the part
Layers far apart Layers do not stick together Layer height Low temperature
Excess plastic Plastic "blobs" form during printing Hotend mismatch
Deficient first layer The lines do not join, cracks form and the material detaches from the base Layer height Low temperature Lines too close together
Contribute
Support Idea 3D
Hello, I am Néstor, creator of the Idea 3D app. I want to thank all the makers who have used our platform and who have provided us with valuable feedback. As you know, Idea 3D is a free application that we have developed with the aim of helping the community of makers and users of 3D printers.\n
However, the development and maintenance of this application requires continuous effort and resources. That\'s why today I ask for your financial support to help us continue improving Idea 3D and offer a better experience for all users. Any contribution you make will be invested directly in the development and maintenance of our platform.\n
I want to highlight that Idea 3D will continue to be a free application. We are not looking for economic benefits with this financing campaign, but simply resources to improve our platform and make it even more useful for all users. We are committed to offering a tool that helps the community of makers and we are grateful for any contribution you can make to help us achieve this goal.\n
Thank you for your support and for being part of the maker community. Together we can make a better and more useful platform for everyone.

When there is an excessive temperature in the hotend, plastic may not come out in the first seconds.
Enable the "Skirt" option, so that the head purges. If material comes out of the nozzle for more than 20 seconds when the melter is stopped, the temperature should be reduced. IMPORTANT: the extruder must retract at least 10mm whenever it enters the idle position so that the cooling is done in the teflon area and the start-up is correct. Check that in the last lines of the gcodes this retraction occurs, otherwise add two lines: 1.- G92 E0 and 2.- G1 E-15 F6000. If the bed is already correctly leveled, we have to determine the proper height of the Nozzle with respect to it, in one of the following ways:
On some models, what we can do is lower the Z-axis limit switch, in this way, what we do is decrease the nozzle distance with respect to the bed. Hardware adjustment of the nozzle height. For this we must take into account the Z offset parameter. In this parameter, what we do is to tell the printer to bring "-x mm" the nozzle closer to the hot bed. The first necessary check is to confirm that the proper diameter of the filament used for printing has been set. This can be verified by using a gauge to accurately measure the filament diameter. On the market, the following standard values are available: 1.75 mm or 3 mm. When we do not have enough experience it can happen that more plastic is extruded than necessary, some printers do not have mechanisms to control the plastic flow.
Adjust the filament parameters in your laminating program. You will need to increase the diameter to reduce the amount of plastic extruded by the machine or reduce the multiplier factor.
Example: Diameter: 1.75mm (change to 1.80mm). Correct the number of solid top layers that have been set and what infill we have set during part printing.
For example, if you have set a 10% infill and two solid top layers, you will most likely get gaps as in the image. You should increase the number of solid top layers in order to make sure it is 100% solid.
The Retract parameter determines how much plastic is retracted on head travel when not printing. The more filament that is retracted, the less it will overflow through the nozzle. If your extruder is direct-drive, the appropriate value is between 1 and 1.5mm.
If the retraction is too fast, the filament can create bubbles inside the nozzle or a fast movement of the pulley can bite the filament. Normal working values are between 30-60mm/sec. This parameter may vary a little depending on the type of filament we are printing, it will be the manufacturer itself to provide those values.
If we do not have layer ventilation, this may be the main reason.
In case of having ventilation, it may be that the airflow is not properly configured. To change that option, you have to access the filament configuration parameters and set the correct "Cooling" parameters.
Excessive speed can cause some motor to lose steps. If the displacements are too fast, reduce the displacement speed by 50% without extrusion.
The pressure exerted on the filament on the motor is not correct.
GREG\'S WADE EXTRUDER: the two screws that tighten the filament are too loose. It can also be that the bearing that pushes the filament against the hobbed bolt does not rotate smoothly.
EXTRUSOR DIRECT DRIVE: the pulley on the motor may not be in perfect condition. Clean the teeth and check that they are not worn. It may also be that the cam is not exerting enough pressure.
Check that the hotend thermistor is in place, this may cause the nozzle not to be at the set temperature.
Check that the melt temperature is correct, check the lamination parameters making sure that we have chosen the right material and color. The tube inside the hotend rod may be damaged and should be replaced. If the infill print speed is too high, the layers may not merge properly. The solution would be to slow down the infill print speed.
During head movements, the extruder should retract to avoid plastic dripping. If this is not the case, we can find remains of filament causing that the piece does not have a good finish.
If the retraction is too fast, the filament can create bubbles inside the nozzle or a fast movement of the pulley can bite the filament. Normal working values are between 30-60mm/sec. This parameter may vary a little depending on the type of filament we are printing.
If it occurs at the end of the layer we modify the parameter "Extra length on restart"..
We can try modifying the parameter that controls the percentage ratio between the perimeter and the infill, called "Infill/Perimeter Overlap". This parameter indicates what percentage of infill overlaps the perimeters. If we have the problem as in the figure we should increase the value of this parameter and test that it has been solved.
We can try increasing the "Infill/Perimeter Overlap" parameter by 30%. If it is not enough, increase this parameter further.
If you notice that from the beginning the first layers peel off, see section "The first layer does not adhere to the base". This effect appears if the first layer is printed too close to the glass. The Z-axis is not correctly calibrated and the nozzle touches the glass preventing the plastic from coming out easily. This problem is observed during the printing of the first layer.
Lower the hot bed of the printer if your printer allows it.
Adjusting the nozzle height using software: To do this we must take into account the Z offset parameter. With this parameter what we do is to indicate to the printer that the Z axis zero point is at "x mm" from the homming point.
This error occurs when the Z axis has backlash and the linear movement of this axis is not straight. This backlash can occur for several reasons: *Smooth rods: one of the smooth rods moves or vibrates. Fix correctly. *Threaded rods: check that they are straight and concentric with the motors. *Z-axis nuts: make sure that the nuts that allow the Z-axis movement are fixed.
You should check and adjust the speed parameters of the printing movements of your machine. Gradually reduce the values until you get a good print of the part.
You can try modifying the parameter that controls the percentage ratio between perimeter and infill, called "Infill/Perimeter Overlap". This parameter indicates what percentage of infill overlaps the perimeters. If we have the problem as in the figure we should increase the value of this parameter and test that it has been solved.
We can try increasing the "Infill/Perimeter Overlap" parameter by 30%. If it is not enough, increase this parameter further..
Change the nozzle for a smaller diameter nozzle.
We must keep in mind that the highest layer resolution will be 80% of the nozzle diameter.
For example, with a 0.3mm nozzle we can print layers with a maximum height of 0.24mm (0.3mm*80%=0.24mm)..
The layer height can never be more than 80% of the nozzle diameter. For example, if we have a 0.3 mm nozzle, the maximum layer height will be 0.24 mm.
The nozzle and threaded rod may not be tightened well together. The threaded rod and nozzle must be tightened well. HOT (at 240º), this is very important because otherwise the hotend may break because of the hardened plastic, hold the square with a pliers and screw the nozzle until it stops. Another important thing is not to overtighten as the hotend materials are somewhat delicate.
Decrease the height of the first layer. Remember that the maximum height cannot exceed 80% of the nozzle diameter.
The extruder is probably clogged. This may be caused because some plastic has been left inside the Nozzle preventing the plastic from flowing. The extruder needs to be disassembled, see the printer manual or contact the manufacturer for the steps to follow.
As a general rule the first layer should be done at half the speed of the rest of the print. In this way what we do is to make sure that the filament adheres to the base. This is solved by modifying the parameter called "First Layer Speed". If we indicate 50%, we are telling the printer to print the first layer at half the speed of the rest of the layers. If you find that it is still too fast, decrease the value..
Adjust the value of the "extrusion multiplier". By modifying this parameter what we achieve is to vary how much plastic is extruded on each print. For example, the default value is set to 1, but if we increase it to 1.15, it means that 15% more plastic will be extruded than before. The typical value for PLA filament is 0.9, while for ABS filament it tends to be about 1.0. If you make any modifications, it is advisable to perform a calibration test print to check that the problem has been fixed..
If the fill percentage is below correct, voids will appear on the top faces, the support surface is too small and the filament may sag. To fix this, you will have to increase it from the infill parameter of your laminator.
An incorrect extrusion temperature is one of the most frequent problems. If the temperature is too high, the filament inside the nozzle becomes too viscous and comes out without the extruder running. Try lowering the extruder temperature by 5–10 degrees, if in idle position the plastic is still coming out continue lowering the temperature.
If even with fan, the problem persists, you should try lowering the extruder temperature. This way you will get the filament to solidify faster.
Too much or too little tension in the belts causes irregularities in the motion transmission. Adjusting the belts is part of the periodic maintenance of a printer, refer to the printer manual to perform it correctly.
Extruding too fast can cause more plastic to be extruded than the hotend is capable of pulling through the nozzle. We can adjust the flow of plastic that will be ejected during printing, we can slow down the speed and keep testing, until we manage to solve the problem.
Extract the filament and cut the worn segment to remove any impurities that may exist in that section. Reload the filament and with the hotend hot push manually to check that it comes out of the nozzle without exerting excessive pressure.
Remove the filament and cut the worn segment to remove any impurities that may exist in that section. Reload the filament and with the hotend hot push manually to check that it comes out of the nozzle without exerting excessive pressure.
It is possible that the fill pattern used is not the right one for the part you want to print. Change the fill pattern parameter on your laminator and go testing.
Extruding too fast can cause more plastic to be extruded than the hotend is capable of pulling through the nozzle. We can adjust the flow of plastic to be extruded during printing, we can reduce the speed and try it out, until the problem is solved.
If you print at a very high speed, the layers may not merge properly. A possible solution might be to slow down the print speed of the top layer fill.
If your printer does not have an enclosed structure, any draft can cause the material to retract too far and peel off the base. You should try to control the printing environment as much as possible.
If the bed is already properly leveled, you need to determine the proper height of the Nozzle relative to the bed in one of the following ways:
On some models, what we can do is lower the Z-axis limit switch, in this way, what we do is decrease the nozzle distance with respect to the bed. Hardware adjustment of the nozzle height. For this we must take into account the Z offset parameter. In this parameter, what we do is to tell the printer to bring "-x mm" the nozzle closer to the hot bed.
If any of your printer\'s firmware acceleration settings have been modified, they may not be optimal for proper operation.
You should contact technical support for guidance on how to proceed appropriately.
Increase by parameter the perimeter width if it is too small. You can start by setting the parameter to the same size as the nozzle. This is a good size for most laminators. For example, if we have a 0.3mm nozzle we should set this parameter to a value of 0.3..
You can tell the laminator that you have a lower resolution nozzle than the one you have, and thus get it to print with more detail.
Although in a way we are "fooling" the printer, so part could have other problems associated with this solution.. If the layer height is appropriate, it is possible that the extruded filament is at a lower temperature than necessary for the type of plastic it uses. You should check the extrusion temperature until you get the proper temperature for the filament being used.
Increase the first layer temperature setting on your laminator.
If the bed is already properly leveled, we need to determine the proper height of the Nozzle relative to the bed in one of the following ways:
On some models, what we can do is lower the Z-axis limit switch, in this way, what we do is decrease the nozzle distance with respect to the bed. Hardware adjustment of the nozzle height. For this we must take into account the Z offset parameter. In this parameter, what we do is to tell the printer to bring "-x mm" the nozzle closer to the hot bed.
If you print filament on a cold bed, it is normal that the plastic cools faster causing it not to stick. To solve this, if the printer has a hot base, you should increase the temperature until you get better adhesion. The temperature of the hot base depends on the type of filament we are using, the manufacturer itself indicates the temperature that must be set to print. It is also important to use adhesive or fixative to improve adhesion.
On the other hand, if we have layer fan, disable it for the first one.
The first thing to check is that you have set the correct diameter of the filament being printed. You can check with a caliper exactly what diameter the filament is. There are the following market values: 1.75mm or 3mm.
Adjust the value of the "extrusion multiplier". By modifying this parameter what we achieve is to vary how much plastic is extruded in each print. For example, the default value is set to 1, but if we increase it to 1.15, it means that 15% more plastic will be extruded than before. The typical value for PLA is 0.9 and for ABS is 1.0.
If adjusting the above parameters the problems continue, we can try enabling the "Avoid crossing perimeters" option.
When printing at a very high speed, the layers do not cool down before depositing the next layer.
The electronics have control drivers for the stepper motors, if they are not set to the proper mA, the motor will lose steps and the layers will shift. If we have a multimeter, what we will do is to adjust the current of each motor axis according to the printer we have (you can try with X=400 mA , Y=400 mA, Z=E=600 mA, when they are DRV8825, otherwise consult the optimal values for the type of driver you have). If in doubt, consult the manufacturer.
Each material has a suitable temperature range and even depending on the color, by its dye, could vary, in case that, during printing, the temperature is not optimal, the plastic may not extrude properly and cause the filament to "bite". You will have to vary the hotend temperature until the ideal temperature is reached. If the above solutions have not solved the problem, you should disassemble the hotend and check what is happening inside.
During a long print, it may be the case that the extruder motor overheats, causing the extruder control driver to deactivate the motor, stopping extruding filament. This is caused because the mA of the driver is not properly adjusted. The electronics have control drivers for the stepper motors, if they are not set to the appropriate mA, the motor will lose steps and the layers will move. If we have a multimeter, what we will do is adjust the current of each motor axis according to the printer we have. If in doubt, consult the manufacturer.
Adjust the “extrusion multiplier” value. By modifying this parameter what we achieve is to vary how much plastic is extruded in each print. For example, by default the value is set to 1, but if we increase it to 1.15, it means that 15% more plastic will be extruded than previously. The typical value for PLA filament is 0.9, while for ABS filament it tends to be around 1.0. If you make any modifications, it is advisable to perform a calibration test print to verify that the problem has been solved.
Insufficient top layers. Increase "Top layers" parameter
If you are printing with ABS filament, you will need to use a fixative or adhesive so that the first layer sticks correctly. When printing with this type of plastic it is convenient to create a “brim” around the piece. “Brim” creates a plastic platform around the part, which improves its adhesion.
An excess or lack of tension in the belts causes irregularities in the transmission of motion. Adjusting the belts is part of the periodic maintenance of a printer, consult its manual to do it correctly.
As a last option, we can modify the design of the piece to ensure that the walls that are thinner can be printed better.
You must increase the line width of the first layer, at most twice the diameter of the nozzle.
